key_points: Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen accused the company of prioritizing profit over combating hate speech and misinformation.
Haugen's lawyers filed at least eight complaints with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
Haugen revealed her identity on the CBS program "60 Minutes," following a series of Wall Street Journal stories that scrutinized Facebook's practices.
The whistleblower will testify at a Senate subcommittee hearing titled "Protecting Kids Online" regarding Instagram's impact on teens.
Haugen claimed Facebook was aware of its platforms fostering discord and harming teens but prioritized its financial interests.
Allegations include Facebook's role in organizing the Capitol riot on January 6, by deactivating safety systems post-election.
Facebook contested Haugen's accusations, with spokesperson Lena Pietsch asserting ongoing improvements in curbing harmful content.
Facebook VP of global affairs Nick Clegg called the idea that social media caused the January 6 Capitol riot "ludicrous."
Haugen's attorney confirmed sharing internal documents with several state attorneys general and expressed intentions to discuss regulatory actions internationally.
Whistleblower Aid launched a GoFundMe to support Haugen's legal expenses.
spokespersons: Frances Haugen (Product Manager, Civic Misinformation Team, Facebook)
Nick Clegg (Vice President of Global Affairs, Facebook)
